questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms after consuming poorly cooked meat. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs or gravid proglottids, suggesting a diagnosis of taeniasis. Which of the following statements regarding the causative agents of this infection is correct?

options.A: The eggs of Taenia saginata are infective to humans
options.B: The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis
options.C: The eggs of Taenia solium are not infective to humans.
options.D: Taenia solium is acquired through poorly cooked beef

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis. Explanation: Cysticercus bovis is the infective larval stage found in cattle, which can be transmitted to humans through the consumption of poorly cooked beef. Taenia Species T. saginata T.solium Definitive Host Man Man Intermediate Host Cattle (cow or buffalo) Pig Larva Cysticercus bovis; present in cow not in man Cysticercus cellulosae; present in pig and also in man Egg Not infective to man (Option A) Infective to man (Option C) Mode of Infection Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked cattle (cow or buffalo) meat. Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked pig meat. (Option D) Diagnostic Form Eggs or gravid proglottids in feces Infective Form Cysticercus bovis (Option B) Cysticercus cellulosae Life Cycle:

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. A stool sample is analyzed, revealing the presence of eggs that are oval in shape, have a smooth outer surface, and lack an operculum similar to the image given below. Given these findings, which of the following treatments is the most appropriate for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Praziquantel Explanation: Praziquantel is the drug of choice for treating infections caused by Hymenelopis dimunata . It works by increasing the permeability of the parasite's cell membrane to calcium ions , leading to paralysis and death of the parasite. Hymenolepis diminuta Hymenolepis diminuta, or rat tapeworm, is a parasitic tapeworm that primarily infects rodents but can occasionally infect humans through ingestion of infected insects. Morphology Adult Worm: Large (20-60 cm) and slender, with a scolex that lacks hooks and has four suckers for attachment. Composed of many proglottids with both male and female organs. Egg: Eggs of H. diminuta are slightly oval, larger than those of H. nana, measuring around 60-80 µm in diameter. They have a thick outer shell, a yellowish color, and lack polar filaments ( distinguishing them from H. nana eggs). Inside, there is an oncosphere (embryo) with six hooks that will aid in initial attachment upon ingestion by the insect host. Life Cycle Intermediate Host (Insects): Eggs ingested by insects (e.g., beetles, fleas) develop into cysticercoid larvae. Definitive Host (Rodent/Human): Infection occurs when an insect with

questions.question: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hymenolepis nana Explanation: This is an egg of Hyenopelsis nana. Size: 30–50 µ m in diameter. Shape: Oval or spherical with a thin shell. Inner membrane/embryophore: Characterized by polar filaments extending into the space between the inner and outer shell. Embryo: Contains an oncosphere with three pairs of hooklets. Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm) Hymenolepis nana, or dwarf tapeworm, is a parasitic cestode primarily infecting humans and rodents, commonly causing infection in children. It can complete its life cycle in a single host without requiring an intermediate host. Morphology Adult Worm: Measures 15–40 mm in length; features a scolex with four suckers and a retractable rostellum with hooks for attachment to the intestinal wall. Proglottids: Segmented body, with each segment containing both male and female reproductive organs. Life Cycle Infective Stage: Eggs are excreted in feces and can survive in the environment. Autoinfection: Ingested eggs hatch in the intestine, allowing direct development into adults, leading to reinfection. Ingestion: Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated food or water. Rodents can also act as hosts. Larval Development: Oncospheres hatch in the intestine, penetrate intestinal villi, and develop into cysticercoids. Maturation: Cysticercoids mature into adults in about 20–30 days, attaching to the intestinal wall and producing eggs. Clinical features Asymptomatic in many cases. Symptomatic individuals may experience: Abdominal pain and cramps Diarrhea or loose stools Loss of appetite and weight loss Irritability (especially in children) Nausea and vomiting

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta?

options.A: H. nana has hooks on its rostellum; H. diminuta does not
options.B: H. nana requires two intermediate hosts; H. diminuta requires one
options.C: H. diminuta exhibits autoinfection; H. nana does not
options.D: H. nana is the rat tapeworm; H. diminuta is the dwarf tapeworm

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) H. nana has hooks on its rostellum; H. diminuta does not. Explanation: Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta Feature Hymenolepis nana (H. nana) Hymenolepis diminuta (H. diminuta) Common Name (Option D) Dwarf tapeworm Rat tapeworm Definitive Hosts Humans, rodents Primarily rodents, occasionally humans Intermediate Host (Option B) Optional , can complete life cycle in a single host Required , typically insects (e.g., beetles, fleas) Egg Oval and 37 to 47 µm in diameter, and has a double-layered shell that encloses filaments arising from bipolar thickenings Rounder and 60 to 85 µm in diameter and have no polar filaments . Adult Size 15-40 mm long 20-60 cm long Scolex (Option A) Four suckers, retractable rostellum with hooks Four suckers, no hooks Infective Stage Embryonated eggs (directly infective) Cysticercoid larva in the intermediate host Mode of Transmission (Option C) Fecal-oral, autoinfection possible Ingestion of infected intermediate host Life Cycle Simple, can complete cycle within one host Complex, requires two hosts Diagnostic Method Identification of eggs in stool samples Identification of eggs in stool samples Treatment Praziquantel or niclosamide Praziquantel Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page: 136-139. Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Practical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page: 450. https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/hymenolepiasis/index.html

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with liver imaging that reveals a cystic mass with an invasive, infiltrative growth pattern spreading into surrounding tissues. Serology confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following species is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) E. multilocularis Explanation: E. multilocularis is responsible for alveolar echinococcosis , known for its invasive, infiltrative growth pattern that lacks a well-defined capsule, allowing the infection to spread similarly to malignant tumors, especially within the liver. Echinococcus multilocularis Echinococcus multilocularis is a parasitic tapeworm causing alveolar echinococcosis (AE) in humans. It primarily infects the liver, forming tumour-like lesions that can infiltrate surrounding tissues and spread to other organs. Epidemiology: Found in Europe, Asia, and North America, with rural residents in contact with foxes or dogs at higher risk. Pathology: Multiloculated, invasive liver cysts lacking a true capsule, resembling malignant tumors. It also affects the lungs, spleen, and brain by metastasis. Life Cycle: Definitive hosts: Foxes, dogs, and other canids host adult worms in their intestines, shedding eggs in feces. Intermediate hosts: Rodents ingest eggs, which hatch, migrate to the liver, and form multilocular cysts. Accidental hosts (humans): Humans ingest eggs from contaminated sources, with larvae forming invasive cysts primarily in the liver. Clinical presentation: It is often asymptomatic initially but can progress to symptoms like abdominal pain, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. If untreated, the disease may spread to other organs, such as the lungs, brain, and bones. Investigations: Imaging: Ultrasound: Detects irregular liver cysts. CT/MRI: Defines extent and spread of cysts. Serology: ELISA/Immunoblot: Detect antibodies against E. multilocularis. Histopathology: Confirms the presence of larval elements when a biopsy is performed. Management: Surgery: Radical Resection: Preferred for curative treatment. Liver Transplantation: Considered for extensive, unresectable disease. Pharmacotherapy: Albendazole: The main drug used, often requiring prolonged or lifelong treatment. Echinococcus multilocularis (Alveolar Echinococcosis) and Echinococcus granulosus (Cystic Echinococcosis): Feature Echinococcus multilocularis (Alveolar Echinococcosis) Echinococcus granulosus (Cystic Echinococcosis) (Option A) Cyst Structure Multi-chambered, invasive, tumor-like growth Single, large fluid-filled cyst with thick laminated wall Growth Pattern Infiltrative, resembles malignancy, spreads to nearby tissues Expansive, non-invasive, contained within a single cyst Common Sites Primarily liver Can metastasise (e.g., lungs, brain) Mostly liver, sometimes lungs Calcification Common, granular appearance on imaging Less common, cyst typically has a " water lily " sign Treatment Complex; surgery and long-term albendazole, poor prognosis Surgery is often effective, sometimes with albendazole E. vogeli (Option C) : E. vogeli causes polycystic formations, usually forming multiple cysts within a compact mass that mainly affects the liver but without the aggressive invasive behaviour of E. multilocularis. E. oligarthrus (Option D) : E. oligarthrus is a rare cause of polycystic formations in humans, primarily affecting animals, and does not display the invasive growth pattern seen with E. multilocularis.

questions.question: A 39-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal mass. Ultrasound imaging shows findings depicted in the accompanying image. Based on the WHO classification of hydatid cysts, to which stage does this cyst correspond?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CE 3 Explanation: CE 3 is characterized by the presence of the "water lily sign," indicating a cyst with a detached membrane floating within the cyst cavity, which is a hallmark of this stage. Investigations for Echinococcus granulosus Imaging Studies Ultrasound (USG): USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement. Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour). WHO Classification Cyst Type Ultrasound Findings CL Unilocular Cyst Cystic lesion and no visible cyst wall CE1 (Option A) Simple Active Cyst Double-line sign ; well-defined anechoic cyst CE2 (Option B) Multivesicular Cyst Honeycomb appearance: Visible cyst wall and internal septations CE3 Transitional Cyst Have detached laminar membranes or may be partially collapsed, and floating within the cyst cavity ( Water-lily sign ) CE4 (Option D) Inactive Cyst Non-homogenous mass CE5 Inactive Cyst Cyst with a thick calcified wall CT Scan : For detection of extrahepatic disease. MRI: For detection of cyst in difficult sites such as spinal vertebrae and cardiac cysts. Serological Tests: ELISA : Primary serological test sensitive for antibodies against E. granulosus . Immunoblotting : Highly specific for confirming equivocal

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and occasional fever. On examination, a palpable mass is detected in the right upper quadrant. The patient mentions a recent trip to a region known for livestock farming. An ultrasound reveals a cystic structure with characteristic internal septations. Based on these findings, which layer of the cyst is primarily involved in protecting the parasite from the host's immune system?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A Explanation: Ectocyst (A), or laminated membrane, serves as a barrier that prevents the host’s immune system from recognizing and attacking the cyst. Its unique structure minimizes immune detection and enhances parasite survival. hydatid cyst Labelled" data-author="" data-hash="10181" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="400" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/FdOozmbtODTEKYe6di6O1744476623.png" width="400" /> Hydatid Cyst Hydatid cysts are parasitic cysts caused by Echinococcus granulosus. Commonly Affected Organs Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases) Lungs (second most common site) Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum Clinical Features Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst

questions.question: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with hydatid cysts. Which of the following serves as the accidental intermediate host in this infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Human Explanation: Humans act as accidental intermediate hosts for hydatid cysts by ingesting eggs from contaminated sources, often due to close contact with infected dogs. Echinococcus granulosus: Other name Dog tapeworm Definitive Host Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox (Option A & B) Intermediate Host Sheep and cattle (Option C) Accidental Intermediate Host Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form) (Option D) Infective Form Embryonated egg Mode of Infection Ingestion of the eggs due to: Intimate handling of infected dogs Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces Eggs Ovoid in shape and brown in color Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets Larva Represent the structure of the scolex of the adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body. Adult Worm Consists of scolex, a short neck and strobila Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets. Life Cycle:

questions.question: A 34-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal discomfort and reports passing segments in stool. Stool microscopy shows Taenia eggs, but further tests are needed for species identification. Which test best differentiates Taenia saginata from Taenia solium, and what is the drug of choice?

options.A: MRI to detect non-calcified cysts; Praziquantel
options.C: Microscopy of gravid proglottids to count lateral uterine branches; Praziquantel
options.D: Stool concentration using the formol-ether sedimentation method; Albendazole

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Microscopy of gravid proglottids to count lateral uterine branches; Praziquantel saginata having 15-20 lateral uterine branches and T. solium having fewer than 13. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for treating intestinal taeniasis. Laboratory Diagnosis: Intestinal Taeniasis: Stool Microscopy: Shows characteristic eggs of Taenia but can’t differentiate T. solium and T.saginata Concentration method: Formol ether sedimentation method (Option D) Microscopy of Gravid Proglottids: (Option C) Can be done for species identification. 15-20 lateral uterine branches: T. saginata <13 lateral uterine branches: T. solium Cysticercosis: Biopsy of Lesion: Show invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks scolex with suckers and hooks" data-author="Thiriveni Balajji, M.D. and M. Kavitha, M.D." data-hash="10174" data-license="NA" data-source="https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorcysticercosis.html" data-tags="April2025" height="209" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/5onYLvLTYnUBrBz8Q1YS1744476101.png" width="400" /> X-ray: For detecting calcified cysticerci in subcutaneous tissue and muscles CT scan of the Brain: For detecting dead calcified cysts MRI scan: Detection of noncalcified cysts, spinal cysticerci and ventricular cysts. (Option A) ELISA: For detection of anti-cysticercus antibodies in serum and CSF. (Option B) Treatment: Intestinal Taeniasis: Single dose of Praziquantel (drug of choice) Cysticercosis: Excision is the best treatment, wherever possible. Neurocysticercosis: Praziquantel + Albendazole Glucocorticoids must be started before starting albendazole, as the killed larval forms released from the cyst can cause inflammation.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with a history of multiple painless subcutaneous nodules (shown below), seizures, and recent neurological symptoms. The patient has a history of consuming undercooked pork. Microscopy of a biopsy from one of the subcutaneous nodules reveals larval forms with a scolex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Neurocysticercosis Explanation: The combination of subcutaneous nodules, seizures, and neurological symptoms in a patient with a history of consuming undercooked pork suggests neurocysticercosis. Cysticercosis Infection direct consumption of T. solium eggs via contaminated food Caused by the larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of Taenia solium. Pathology Can affect any organ or tissue, with the most common sites being subcutaneous tissues and muscles. Other affected areas include Eyes and the brain Less often, heart, liver, lungs, abdominal cavity and spinal cord. Cysticercus is surrounded by a fibrous capsule except in the eye and brain ventricles. The larvae trigger a cellular reaction , initially involving neutrophils, eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and occasionally giant cells. This reaction leads to fibrosis , death of the larva, and eventual calcification . Clinical Features Depends on the affected site: Subcutaneous cysticercosis: Mostly presents as asymptomatic nodules. Muscular cysticercosis: May cause acute myositis. Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of the brain): Most common and severe form. Second most common cause of intracranial space-occupying lesions

questions.question: Identify the correct feature of the given group of organisms.

options.A: They have a complete alimentary canal

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) They are hermaphrodites Explanation: The image given is that of cestodes, which include Taenia solium, T. saginata , and other long flat worms. Cestodes are hermaphrodites (having both male and female sex organs). Intestinal helminths: Can be classified as cestodes, trematodes, and nematodes. These cause many gastrointestinal infections. Cestodes Trematodes Nematodes These are long and segmented worms. These are leaf-like and unsegmented. These are elongated unsegmented worms. They are dorsoventrally flattened and have no body cavity . (Option D) These are also flatworms without a body cavity. These are cylindrical worms and have a body cavity with well-differentiated organs. They have no alimentary canal . (Option A) They have an incomplete alimentary canal without an anus. They have a complete alimentary canal. They have suckers for attaching to the host. Some have hooks as well. (Option B) Suckers are present. Hooks are absent. Hooks and suckers are absent. These are hermaphrodites (monoecious) (Option C) Hermaphrodites except Schistosoma. The sexes are separate (diecious) Examples: Diphyllobothrium Taenia saginata Taenia solium Echinococcus granulosus Hymenolepis nana Dipylidium caninum Examples: Intestinal flukes: Fasciolopsis buski Blood flukes: Schistosoma mansoni Examples: Small intestinal nematodes: Ascaris Hookworm Strongyloides Large intestinal: Trichuris Enterobius

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain and diarrhea. A stool examination reveals the presence of tapeworm segments. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Taenia saginata and Taenia solium? branches

options.A: T. saginata has a small globular scolex, while T. solium has a large quadrate scolex.
options.B: T. saginata has fewer than 1000 proglottids, whereas T. solium has more than 1000
options.C: T. saginata possesses rostellum and hooks, while T. solium lacks rostellum and hooks
options.D: T. saginata has thin, dichotomous uterine branches, while T. solium has thick, dendritic uterine

questions.explanation: dendritic uterine branches Correct Answer: D) T. saginata has thin, dichotomous uterine branches, while T. solium has thick, dendritic branches. Explanation: Feature Taenia saginata No Taenia solium Image Length 5-10 meters 2-3 meters Scolex (Option A & C) Large quadrate Rostellum and hooks are absent Suckers may be pigmented Small and globular Rostellum and hooks are present Suckers not pigmented Neck Long Short Proglottids (Option B) 1000-2000 Below 1000 Measurement (gravid segment) 20 mm X 5 mm 12 mm X 6 mm Expulsion Expelled singly Expelled passively in chains of 5 or 6 Uterus (Option D) Lateral branches 15-30 on each side; thin and dichotomous Lateral branches 5-10 on each side; thick and dendritic Vagina Present Absent Accessory lobe of ovary Absent Present Testes 300-400 follicles 15-200 follicles

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of tingling in her hands and feet, along with weakness and fatigue. She has a history of consuming undercooked fish. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia and elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV). A stool examination shows operculated eggs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Diphyllobothrium latum infection Explanation: The patient’s history of consuming undercooked fish along with Macrocytic anemia and elevated MCV indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency, strongly suggesting a Diphyllobothrium latum infection, as this parasite is associated with infected freshwater fish . Additionally, the stool examination reveals operculated eggs , which are characteristic of Diphyllobothrium latum . Diphyllobothrium latum Clinical Features Most infections are asymptomatic ; only a few individuals develop symptoms. Minor Symptoms: These may include abdominal discomfort, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and weight loss. Rarely, patients may experience acute abdominal pain due to intestinal obstruction, cholangitis, or cholecystitis. Vitamin B12 Deficiency: The adult worm interferes with the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex , leading to decreased absorption in the ileum, resulting in megaloblastic anemia (bothriocephalus anemia) and neurological sequelae (e.g., paresthesia). (Option B) Laboratory Diagnosis Stool Examination: Identifies characteristic operculated eggs ; they are: Bile-stained, Operculated with a knob. Do not float in the saturated salt solution. Diphyllobothrium latum" data-author="Stefan Walkowski " data-hash="10154" data-license="CC BY-SA 4.0" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diphyllobothrium#/media/File:Diphyllobothrium_latum_egg.jpg" data-tags="April2025" height="274" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4BLEhQxCHDe2wAJGjkU81744474648.png" width="400" /> Molecular Testing: PCR and sequencing allow for precise species identification. Blood Tests: Eosinophilia and megaloblastic anaemia indicators include: Increased MCV & MCH Normal MCHC Macrocytes Treatment Drug of Choice: Praziquantel (5–10 mg/kg once). Alternative Option: Niclosamide. Parenteral vitamin B12 should be administered if B12 deficiency is evident. Schistosoma haematobium infection (Option A) is linked to freshwater exposure and typically presents with urinary symptoms. Eggs are found in urine, not stool. Hookworm (Option C) causes iron deficiency anemia rather than vitamin B12 deficiency. The stool would not reveal operculated eggs, as hookworm eggs are not operculated. Fasciola / Liver fluke (Option D) has a round and operculated egg similar to the one in this scenario. However, it does not lead to vitamin B12 deficiency but rather causes fever, diarrhea, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, hepatomegaly, myalgias, and urticarial rash. Reference: Apurba S Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, 3rd edition, Page: 451, 452. Fascioliasis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A medical student is studying various parasitic infections and learns that certain parasites are characterized by operculate eggs. Which of the following parasites is not associated with operculate eggs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Schistosoma mansoni Explanation: The eggs of Schistosoma mansoni are oval and possess a distinctive spine, but they lack an operculum . In contrast, other trematodes have operculate eggs, which are characterised by a lid-like structure at one end. Egg of Diphyllobothrium latum Diphyllobothrium latum" data-author="NA" data-hash="10156" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="300" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/qzKU3MBch8O4ONGO3vi51744474826.png" width="300" /> A single D. latum worm can lay approximately one million eggs daily. Egg is broadly ovoid, about 65 µm by 45 µm, with a thick, light brown shell. It has an operculum at one end and often a small knob at the other. Freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules , with the embryo referred to as an oncosphere , which has six hooklets . Eggs are resistant to chemicals but are vulnerable to drying. Eggs do not float in saturated salt solution and exhibit bile staining . These eggs are not infectious to humans. Parasites with operculate eggs Fasciola hepatica (Option A) Fasciola gigantica Fasciolopsis buski Clonorchis sinensis (Option C) Paragonimus westermani Gastrodiscoides hominis Opisthorchis felineus Opisthorchis viverrini Heterophyes heterophyes (All Trematodes except schistosoma) Diphyllobothrium latum (Option B) Spirometra Reference: Paniker’s textbook of medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Pages: 118, 151.

questions.question: A 28-year-old female with a history of consuming locally caught fish presents with complaints of weakness and mild abdominal pain. Her stool sample reveals eggs, as shown in the figure. Which form of the parasite would have been present in the fish she consumed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Plerocercoid Explanation: This patient likely has a fish tapeworm infection, supported by her history of consuming locally caught fish and finding operculated eggs in her stool. Diphyllobothrium latum infects humans via the consumption of fish containing the infective L3 larva (plerocercoid) . Diphyllobothrium latum Also known as Fish tapeworm/Broad tapeworm , it is the largest and longest cestode found infecting the human intestine. Morphology Adult Worm : Can grow >15 meters in length with more than 3,000 segments (proglottids); has a scolex (head) with two grooves (bothria). No suckers and hooklets. Egg : Operculated structure. Larvae : Develops in three stages: Coracidium (L1) Procercoid (L2) Plerocercoid (L3) Life Cycle Requires 3 hosts: Definitive Host : Humans, cats and dogs, where the adult worm resides in the intestine. 1st Intermediate Host : Cyclops (small crustacean). 2nd Intermediate Host : Fish. Human Infection : Occurs by consuming undercooked fish containing the L3 (plerocercoid) larva. Transmission and Development : In Cyclops : Eggs in water hatch to L1 (coracidium) larva (Option A) , which infects Cyclops and matures to L2 (procercoid) larva (Option B) . In Fish : L2 larva further matures to L3 (plerocercoid) larva (Option C) , the infective form for humans. In Humans : The L3 larva matures into an adult (Option D) in the small intestine and produces eggs that are excreted in feces ( diagnostic form ).

questions.question: A 38-year-old female from a rural farming community presents with upper abdominal pain, weight loss, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, and ultrasound reveals a well-defined cystic lesion in the liver with internal septations. What is the most likely pathogen causing this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Echinococcus Explanation: The cestode Echinococcus is known to cause hydatid cysts in its intermediate host (humans) and hence, it can be called a somatic cestode in man. Intestinal cestodes Somatic cestodes These are commonly found infesting the intestines. These are found in other parts of the body, like muscles, the brain, etc. Taenia saginata: The beef tapeworm Man is the definitive host . Echinococcus : The dog tapeworm Larva causes hydatid disease . Man is an accidental intermediate host . Taenia solium: The pork tapeworm Man is the definitive host . Taenia solium (Option A) Larva causes cysticercus cellulosae. Man is the definitive host . Hymenolopis nana: The dwarf tapeworm (Option B) It is the smallest intestinal cestode. Man is the definitive host . No intermediate host. Taenia multiceps Humans are accidental intermediate hosts . Diphyllobothrium latum: The fish tapeworm Man is a definitive host . Spirometra (Option D) Larva causes sparganosis. Man is an accidental intermediate host . Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Pages 116, 119, 121, 123, 129, 130,137.

questions.question: Match the following cestodes with the right features. Organism Features i) Taenia solium a. 4 suckers, no hooks ii) Taenia saginata b. 4 suckers, single row of 20-30 hooks iii) Hymenolopis nana c. 2 suctorial grooves or bothria, no suckers, no hooks iv) Diphyllobothrium latum d. 4 suckers, 2 rows of hooks
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-c Explanation: Morphology of cestodes Cestodes are dorsoventrally flat and segmented intestinal worms that may vary in size from a few millimetres to several meters. They are made of three parts: Head or scolex Neck Trunk Distinguishing features of the different cestodes Cestode Taenia solium Taenia saginata Hymenolepis nana Hymenolepis diminuta Diphyllobothrium latum Echinococcus granulosis Head features 4 suckers 2 rows of hooks 4 suckers No hooks 4 suckers Single row of 20-30 hooks 4 suckers No hooks 2 suctorial grooves or bothria No suckers No hooks 4 suckers 2 rows of hooks Images Taenia solium T. saginata Hymenolepis nana Hymenolepis diminuta Diphyllobothrium latum Echinococcus granulosis

questions.question: A microbiologist is examining the stool sample of a patient suspected to have a helminth infestation. Which of the following methods would be the best to assess bile staining property of helminth eggs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Saline mount Explanation: The best method for assessing bile staining property (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown) and observing the motility of the trophozoites and larvae is the saline mount method. Stool sample processing Microscopic examination of stool samples This is done by two methods: Direct wet mount examination Permanent staining methods Direct wet mount Preparation: Drops of saline and Lugol’s iodine are used on the left and right sides of the slide. Mix ~2 mg of feces to form a smooth suspension. Place a coverslip on the mount for examination under a microscope. Observation: Trophozoites Normal constituents of stool like plant fibers and starch cells can be seen Cellular Elements: Pus cells (in inflammatory diarrhea) Red blood cells (in dysentery) Charcot-Leyden Crystals Types of wet mounts: Saline mount: Uses: Detects trophozoites, cysts, helminth eggs, and larvae. Advantages: Demonstrates motility of trophozoites and larvae. Bile staining property can be assessed (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown). Iodine mount: Advantages: Better visualization of nuclear details in cysts, larvae, and eggs. Disadvantages: Iodine immobilizes and kills parasites , hindering motility observation. (Option A) Bile staining property cannot be assessed. Permanent stained smears This method stains the internal structures. Purpose: For accurate detection of protozoan cysts and trophozoites. Common Stains: Iron-hematoxylin stain. Trichrome stain. Modified acid-fast stain for coccidian parasites (e.g., Cryptosporidium). Sedimentation techniques and Flotation techniques (Options B & D) are concentration techniques used to recover low numbers of parasites in stool samples. Useful for epidemiological studies and assessing treatment response. Detects eggs, cysts, and larvae but does not detect trophozoites, as these get destroyed in the process . Sedimentation techniques : Eggs and cysts settle at the bottom due to higher density. Example: Formalin-ether concentration increases detection sensitivity by 8–10 times. Flotation techniques : Specimens are suspended in a denser medium (e.g., saturated salt solution) in which the eggs and cysts float. Limitations: Cannot concentrate non-floating parasites (e.g., unfertilized Ascaris eggs).

questions.question: Which of the following parasites does not have humans as its definitive host?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Echinococcus granulosus Explanation: Humans are the definitive host of all of the above parasites except for Echinococcus granulosus Hosts A host is an organism that supports a parasite, providing it with nourishment and shelter, and is typically larger than the parasite. Definitive host This is the host where the adult stage of the parasite resides and undergoes sexual reproduction . Examples: Mosquito : Acts as the definitive host for the malaria parasite. Humans : Often serve as definitive hosts for various parasites like Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) (Option D) Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) (Option A) Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm) Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) (Option B) Necator americanus (hookworm) Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) Schistosoma species (blood flukes) Strongyloides stercoralis (threadworm) Intermediate host This host is where the larval stage of the parasite lives or where asexual reproduction occurs. Some parasites may require two different intermediate hosts to complete their life cycle, referred to as the first and second intermediate hosts. Example: Humans are intermediate hosts in: Babesia spp. Echinococcus granulosus (Option C) Echinococcus multiocularis Toxoplasma gondii Plasmodium spp. Paratenic host This type of host allows the larval stage of the parasite to remain viable without further development. It acts as a carrier that can transmit the infection to another host. Example: Fish can serve as a paratenic host for the plerocercoid larva of Diphyllobothrium . Reservoir host In endemic areas, a reservoir host continually maintains the presence of a parasite, serving as a significant source of infection for other susceptible hosts. Example: Dogs are reservoir hosts for hydatid disease . Accidental host This host is not typically part of the parasite's life cycle. Example : Humans can be accidental hosts for cystic echinococcosis . Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page: 1, 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7752/
